Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real-valued functions evolving over time according to the system \\(\\frac{d}{dt}z(t) = Pz(t)\\), with P being a constant matrix. We investigate the effect of a linear transformation \\( g(z) = Qz \\), where Q is also a constant matrix.

If a new transformation \\( h(z) = Rz \\) (where R is another constant matrix) is introduced as an intervention at time \\( t_1 \\), will the endpoint \\( z(T) \\) for T > t_1 depend solely on P, not considering the effects of Q or R?
Explanation: The introduction of \\( h(z) = Rz \\) as an intervention introduces additional dynamics to the evolution of the system. The final state \\( z(T) \\) will be influenced by the transformations \\( Q \\) and \\( R \\) in addition to the matrix P. The interplay of these matrices can change the trajectory significantly.
